content.description: White Trash ascends the first face you encounter on the approach. It's basically a bolted boulder problem.
content.location: The first wall encountered on the approach trail is short, overhanging, and has two routes. This is the left-hand route.

content.description: Beautiful climb--a little bit of everything all the way up! Work the dihedral through jugs, side pulls, and crimps, then stem and find some high feet as you move right over a small roof. After that, it's jugs to the rings.
content.protection: Run-out, for sure. Very easy set-up for top rope though. Climb the ladder over by White Trash and scramble up to the top of the cliff. A trail will cut off to the right, giving you access to two rap rings.
content.location: The dihedral in the main section of The Dump, just left of Pigs in Zen.

content.description: Some people start this route by climbing the chimney which makes the route easier, maybe 10-.
content.location: Start just right of a chimney.  To the left of Vermin.

content.description: Starts with an undercling and a big move to a sharp pinch.  Work your way up then go right at the top through a thin section to gain the anchors.
content.location: Middle of the wall between Voodoo Child and Slimen Hymen.  Shares anchors with Slimen Hymen.

content.description: Excellent steep sport climb for the Boone region. Super solid rock and great holds. A good flow of climbing between protection. Hard lunge crux at the very last move off crimps to a large ledge. If you have the guns, clip the anchor and continue onto upper face to another anchor. This extension is called (Ride the Lightening 13b FA. Joey Henson), which rating includes the entire route with extra finish.
content.location:
Located in the middle of main overhanging wall between Tiers for Allah (far right) and Pigs in Zen.

These original names are unfamiliar to most due to being lost in translation.

content.description: Make sure your undercling game is strong for this one.  Short mid-11 crux getting to the 2nd bolt leads to a slight runout but on very easy terrain. Grab some crimps and thumbercling your way to a multi-move, multiple undercling crux.  Continue up to find jugs in a crack and ready yourself for some dirty and hard to find holdsto gain the anchors.
content.location: between Last Glitch Effort and Black Jackets

content.description:
Climb the easiest sections of two 12's,

Treadin Water (AKA Steady Eddie)

and

Black Jackets

.  Start on Treadin Water and after the second bolt go right on jugs to the 3rd bolt of Black Jackets and finish on Black Jackets.

climbs.name: Top Rope Between Is This How You Clip? and Sidewinder

content.description: Lead Sidewinder or Is This How You Clip?, and clip the anchors to your right (the anchors for Sidewinder). Top rope straight up the face.
content.protection: Use anchors for Sidewinder for a ground-up, fun top rope.
content.location: Between Is This How You Clip? and Sidewinder

content.description: Crux is getting through the roof but hard moves after the roof getting to and clipping the next bolt. The top roof is a crux as well. Fun hard route. First bolted and sent early 1990s. This is when Gus Glitch and I were establishing a lot of new routes here. There has been some strange claims of first accents of this climb like Shoving Joe. I dont know where this comes from but this is my route. Bolted sent numrous times and end of story.
content.location: largest roof at the cliff, centrally located.

content.description: Stimulating thin face climbing. Don't get suckered in to using the arete too much!
content.location: Just right of Dimpsty Dumpster. Follows the bolts just right of the prominent arete.

content.description: A good first sport lead for the grade.  It can also be done traditionally, with so-so placements on the first half and a runout at the crux.
content.protection: Three bolts to rings, first hanger spins, bolt seems solid.
content.location: Short bolted route located on the far left side of the cliff.

content.description: If you are short follow a crimp directly under the bolt, if you are tall you can go big to a hidden pocket out right.  At the top it gets a little slabby.
content.location: Far right route, shares ring anchors with Vermin

content.description: Straightforward up and leftwards, with useful small rails and a few thoughtful moves. Crux is just past 1/3 up, apparently the only move to the right on the whole climb.
content.protection:
4-6 bolts (?) to anchors

The belay stance is a little awkward, beside the steep steps down to the rest of the wall.
content.location: 20 feet right of Is This How You Clip, right before heading down to HomeGrown, Dickcheese, etc.

content.description: This is the extension to Unwritten Law. It adds another V4 boulder problem to the top. Go for it if you're feeling fresh after that dyno!
content.protection: 1 bolt after Unwritten Law, two bolt anchor with fixed carabiners

content.description: Red Headed Stepchild is a new addition to the Dump (2013). The start is often wet but is worth navigating through to reach the overhanging juggy roof finish. Don't forget to knee bar.
content.protection: One of two trad routes at the Dump. A cable sling is around a tree for the anchor. This can be easily set up as a top rope.
content.location: It is located to the right of Son of White Trash.

content.description:
At the risk of confusing matters, I am adding this route, even though this area already lists Greasy Bean Undercling as the chimney line. According to The High Country Cragger (which you really should buy!), Greasy Bean is the three bolt climb just to the left of the chimney.

Start on the sidepull and work straight up to the first bolt. You will start working right toward the chimney as you move to your next bolt. Things get a little weird past the third bolt.
content.protection: Three bolts, with rings on top. HCC has this one as mixed, but gear seemed pretty optional to me.
content.location: The first bolted line to the left of the chimney, at the very end of the 5.12 wall.

content.description:
Start out with some 5.11- climbing up to second bolt. If you fall near the second bolt, you will probably hit the ledge below or the ground. I would strongly recommend working out the moves on top-rope before committing on lead.

Take a quick rest, then prepare to fire up on some tiny crimps and sidepulls for the next 20 feet. Regain your composure and finish up the final easy runout to the anchors.
content.location: Between Warpin Endorphins and Unwritten Law

content.description: Great thin face route. Either bring a stick clip or, for full value, place a bomber nut or two below the crux face. 5.10 crack-ish climbing will bring you to the first bolt and the beginning of a very tenuous, powerful sequence. Crimp your way past two more bolts to the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2-bolt anchor. Either place good gear below the first bolt or figure out some way to stick clip that first bolt, because it's up there.
content.location: Between Suck My Dope and Morphine Endorphin.

content.description: There are multiple interesting cruxes up this beautiful line. Very fun for anyone who enjoys hard face climbing.
content.location: 5.12 wall

climbs.name: Kramer v Kramer
climbs.fa: David Kramer, Mark Terrant, Matt Carter

content.description:
Steep, powerful underclings and crimps lead past several crux sections.

-Mike Grimm's "The High Country Cragger"
content.location: between Here Comes the Rain and Last Glitch Effort

climbs.name: Is This How You Clip?  AKA: Douglas's Excellent Adventure

content.description: Straightforward slab climb.  Additional anchors to the right for toproping.
This climb gets progressively harder the higher you go up on it.  Some say the route is 10a because it gets thin at the last bolt.
content.location: At the far right of the cliff near a water source.  It's the second route from the left on that wall.

content.description:
15 feet right of Fry Cleaned is this dump masterpiece. Often wet at the top. When dry, Rain provides a lesson in extreme underclings, crimps, and sidepulls. Two versions exist. The harder version follows the bolt line straight up, while the easier version trends right of the bolts. A small cam protects the runout between the 1st and 2nd bolt.

-Mike Grimm's "The High Country Cragger"
content.location: between Fry Cleaned and Kramer v Kramer

content.description:
Sent by Ben Hanna, November 2017. Graded 5.13d

Pat Goodman bolted it and after putting all the moves together on TR, never sent it before moving to WV.
content.location: Between Black Jackets and Greasy Bean Undercling

content.description: More of a marker than a route, this chimney splits the Fry-Cleaned wall.
content.protection: Take a small rack with a #3 camalot.
content.location: The obvious chimney in the middle of the Fry Cleaned Wall. Pretty much the only natural feature.

content.description: Engaging, slabbier face climbing. Fun stuff. Climb  interesting but moderate rock up the first 3/4 of the route, then get ready for a stimulating, slopey, smeary crux.
content.location: Just around the corner from the "steep" area. Just right of a prominent arete.

climbs.name: Dumpster Diving
climbs.fa: Ryan Beasley, Jenny Allen (1st toproped, 2001)  (1st lead, Feb. 23, 2014)

content.description: The first crux is clipping and moving pass the third bolt. A second easier crux is pulling over the roof finish.
content.protection: It is a 5 bolt sport route.
content.location: Dumpster Diving is located to the left of the climb up ladder.

content.description: Another bolted boulder problem. Climb steep cranks past two bolts. At the third, either make a move to the arete at right or use little crimps to move left to the top.
content.location: On the first face encountered on the approach (which is short an overhanging). Dimpsty is the right-hand route, just left of an arete.

content.description: Easy climbing leads to a weird move near a vertical crack.  Thinner moves prevail until you get to the anchors.
content.protection:
bolts

NOTE: 2nd to last bolt spins but looks secure.
content.location: Immediately left of homegrown.

content.description: Three crux climb.   Most difficult crux is at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of homegrown.

content.description: Tough start leads to some really easy climbing.  The crux is higher up as you try to go over a bulge with 'nothing' feet.
content.location: 2 routes to the right of Homegrown. Starts above the spring which flows from the rock. Has rap rings.

content.description:
Getting to the second bolt is tricky, reachy and crimpy followed by another hard move to gain jugs and easier climbing.

The name Black Jackets came from the black stripped bees coming out of the ground stinging me during the first accent.
content.location: 3rd bolted line left of Voodoo Child and the chimney.

content.description: There are several technical dump style cruxes; pinches, under-clings, thumber-clings, crimpers and off balance foot sequences. The crux is after bolt #4. Another crux section is before the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts and an optional TCU placement between bolt 2 and 3.
content.location: This route is on the Homegrown Wall. Right of P-Funk.
